description.narrative:
IFEX is a global network of more than 100 organisations in over 70 countries around the world, dedicated to defend and promote freedom of expression and information as a fundamental human right.
IFEX has developed a new five-year strategy for the period 2020-2024. The strategy focuses on four thematic areas, each of them with an overall goal: 1) Right to information - The challenges of access to information, its circulation and integrity, are confronted. 2) Civic Space - Civil society enabled and civic space protected as it relates to Freedom of Expression and Information (FoE&I). 3) Safety and Justice - A safer environment for those exercising their right to FoE&I. 4) Network building - Strengthened capacity of the IFEX network to promote and defend the right to FoE&I.

Insatsen avser ett kärnstöd till yttrandefrihetsnätverket IFEX om totalt 60 MSEK under en femårsperiod 2020-2024. För denna period har IFEX utvecklat en strategi, med fokus på fyra tematiska områden:
1) "Right to information" - med målsättningen att addressera de olika utmaningar som finns kring rätten och tillgång till information.
2) "Civic space" - med målsättningen att de som försvarar yttrandefrihet och rätten till information och de utrymmen som finns stärks och skyddas.
3) "Safety and justice" - med målsättningen att skapa en säkrare miljö för de som utövar sin rätt till yttrandefrihet och information.
4) "Network building" - stärkt kapacitet inom IFEX-nätverket att främja och försvara rätten till yttrandefrihet och information.

In its five-year strategic plan, covering the period 2020-2024, IFEX has identified four key priority areas: 1) Right to information - Goal: The challenges of access to information, its circulation and integrity, are confronted. Objectives: 1. Increased adoption and implementation of robust access to information (ATI) laws and standards by states. 2. Circulation of information online and offline better promoted and defended. 3. Greater action to counter the threats to information integrity online and offline and their impact on Freedom of Expression and Information (FoE&I). 2) Civic Space - Goal: Civil society enabled and civic space protected as it relates to FoE&I. Objectives: 1. Increased network push back against efforts and issues that diminish and/or restrict civic space as it relates to FoE&I. 2. Value of civic space as it relates to FoE&I is acknowledged and reinforced among IFEX's target audience of members, allies, and other engaged individuals and actors. 3) Safety & Justice - Goal: A safer environment for those exercising their right to FoE&I. Objectives: 1. Strengthened normative environment and protection practices for the safety of those exercising their right to FoE&I. 2. Improved justice for those experiencing FoE&I violations. 4) Network building - Goal: Strengthened capacity of the IFEX network to promote and defend the right to FoE&I. Objectives: 1. Enhance member organisational capacity. 2. Enhance meaningful connections between IFEX members. 3. Connections with allies outside the IFEX network are strengthened and diversified.

description.narrative: IFEX is now in its second year of implementation of its strategy and of its current Sida agreement. The strategy was developed based in part on evaluation conclusions (done in 2019). The annual report for 2020 (which is the main basis for this assessment, together with continuous dialogue) depicts how IFEX work seem to have become even more relevant during the Covid pandemic, with especially the urgency of right to information. IFEX and their members often work in complex contexts. Hereunder are some examples of achieved results; Right to information The first International Day for Universal Access to Information (IDUAI) has been celebrated. After years of IFEX supported advocacy by members in Africa who, as part of the African Platform on Access to Information, campaigned to have it recognised by the UN General Assembly. This successful advocacy proved very relevant and timely in 2020. For its first year, IDUAIs theme centered on the right to information in times of crisis, emphasising that having government policies that guarantee public access to information can save lives, build trust, and help the formulation of sustainable policies through and beyond the COVID-19 crisis. IFEX used World Press Freedom Day to get the word out about key IFEX-produced resources, including the web sites Access to Information hub, which IFEX reports received a record number of visits in 2020, reflecting enhanced concerns about access to information that came along with the pandemic. The hub page is continually refreshed with new content, helping readers stay up-to-date with how IFEX members are working to protect press freedom and ensure open, safe, and equitable access to reliable information, both online and offline. Civic Space Pushing back; IFEXs network in Latin America and the Caribbean, IFEX-ALC, published a statement rejecting a draft law in Uruguay that, if passed, would result in a serious setback to the right to freedom of expression and peaceful assembly in the country. The Urgent Consideration Law passed in July 2020, but civil society organisations continue to fight. A new campaign calling for amendments to certain articles of the law, specifically those that give greater powers to the police force during public demonstrations, was launched. Safety and Justice IFEX and their members integrated input into an UN Human Rights Council resolution on the safety of journalists, their input translated into new mentions and recommendations on emerging issues such as extraterritorial threats, over broad and vague laws, strategic lawsuits against public participation (SLAPPs), accreditation regimes, access to information, as well as surveillance and safety during protests. The resolution also strengthened language on gender-specific threats against journalists, and provided guidance on ensuring the safety of journalists in the context of the COVID-19 pandemic and beyond. In early June 2020, after spending nearly three years imprisoned, a human rights activist and co-founder of IFEX members Gulf Centre for Human Rights (GCHR) and Bahrain Centre for Human Rights (BCHR), was finally released. IFEX and local members had continuously advocated for his freedom over the past three years, Network building Throughout 2020, IFEX fostered network solidarity, supported members in their transition to new working realities, and promoted financial sustainability at a time when it was very needed. IFEX provided members with support in strategic planning, invested in members' financial sustainability planning skill-building, provided institutional-strengthening grants, coaching support, cohort skills exchanges, learning opportunities, informational resources and connections with specialists and consultants in a variety of fields.
